I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Promotion of balanced development is a key strategic objective of the Government of 
the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC).  Accordingly,  to  narrow  regional  disparities  in 
development  the  Government  is  shifting  the  focus  of  its  development  promotion  from  the 
eastern  provinces  to  the  relatively  underdeveloped  interior  provinces.  Henan's  provincial 
government  is  eager  to  take  advantage  of  this  shift  in  policy  and  intends  to  utilize  fiscal 
instruments to accelerate the rate of growth in the province. To achieve this objective, the 
Government requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide technical assistance (TA) 
for  Fiscal  Policy  Support  for  Economic  Development  in  Henan.1 The  Henan  government 
proposes to use ADB TA resources to prepare a fiscal policy blueprint, based on analysis and 
in-depth background studies, focusing on the use of fiscal instruments, including those relating 
to expenditure structure optimization. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Henan Province is located in the central region of the PRC, and is the country’s most 
populous province, with over 92 million inhabitants, or about 7.5% of the national population. 
Per capita income in Henan province is below the national average, and the economy is 
dominated by agriculture, mining, and traditional manufacturing, with a relatively small services 
sector. Henan Province is an important producer of farm products, 3 and has two oil fields, coal 
mines, and is rich in nonferrous minerals. The province's manufacturing sector is concentrated 
in six largely traditional industrial sectors—petrochemicals, food processing, nonferrous metals, 
automobiles, textiles, and machinery. With foreign trade constituting a mere 10% of provinces’ 
gross domestic product (GDP), Henan's economy is not as open as those of many other 
provinces.  Henan  has  not  been  successful  in  attracting  a  significant  volume  of  foreign 
investment. 
 
3.  Structural  weaknesses  in  the  economy,  underdeveloped  external  linkages  and  a 
relatively weak private sector presence contribute to Henan’s comparative underdevelopment. 
Due to the preponderance of agriculture, mining and traditional industries in the economy, the 
tax base is moderately narrow and fiscal performance relatively weak. The province raises only 
1.8% of the nation's fiscal revenues, although it has a 6% share of national GDP. Consequently, 
the province’s own sources of revenue cover only 45% of its total spending, resulting in a 
significant reliance on central transfers, which are received in the form of shared taxes, special 
purpose  (earmarked)  grants,  general  block  grants,  and  policy-based  grants  to  implement 
centrally sponsored programs of national importance. 
 
4.  Modernization  of  the  agriculture  sector,  which  has  an  important  place  in  Henan's 
economy,  is  a  major  issue.  Although  it  contributes  only  about  16.5%  of  provincial  GDP, 
agriculture remains a major source of support to about two-thirds of the province's population, 
which resides in rural areas. There is considerable scope for raising agricultural productivity 
through the introduction of new technologies and enhanced use of modern farm inputs and 
practices.  In  recent  years,  the  provincial  government  has  also  promoted  leading  private 
enterprises linked to the farm sector through incentives rather than through direct participation in 
production,  as  in  the  past.  The  provincial  government  is  keen  to  further  strengthen  this 
incentive-based approach.

5.  The industrial sector contributes about 54% of provincial GDP. The province has a 
significant mining industry but profitability is low, in part because of centrally controlled output 
prices. Within the manufacturing sector, petrochemicals, food processing, textiles, nonferrous 
metals, automobiles and parts, and machinery are major industries. State-owned enterprises 
(SOEs)  account  for  the  bulk  of  manufacturing  and  mining  enterprises,  and  these  were 
traditionally responsible for providing many social services. Although many of these social 
responsibilities have been divested from SOEs since 2004, SOE reforms remain a major fiscal 
issue for the provincial government. The government is eager to reduce the number of SOEs, 
which  is  expected  to  fall  from  5,000  in  2007  to  4,500  in  2008.  The  government  is  also 
contemplating other reforms such as separating the supervision function from the State Asset 
Supervision  and  Administration  Commission,  which  controls  SOE  ownership.  The  Finance 
Department intends to pursue deeper reforms in the sector, focused on the creation of an 
environment conducive to private sector investment.  
 
6.  Due to its central location Henan serves as a major transit hub, particularly for railways, 
but it lags behind other provinces in infrastructure penetration. Infrastructure is currently funded 
from several sources, including tolls and central funds, which the central Government raises by 
issuing bonds. These are provided to provincial and local governments in the form of grants for 
non-remunerative infrastructure, and as loans for remunerative projects. Additional funds are 
raised from banks and multilateral institutions. In addition to investing, the Finance Department 
is responsible for (i) due diligence to ensure project viability, (ii) effective project implementation, 
and (iii) prudent use of funds. The government is eager to study other ways of using fiscal 
instruments to stimulate infrastructure investment, including from the private sector.  
 
7.  The provincial government places strategic importance on promoting the services sector 
as an environmentally sustainable means of generating employment and export earnings. In this 
regard,  the  government  seeks  to  assess  where  Henan  Province  enjoys  a  comparative 
advantage, and the potential for development of a modern services industry through the use of 
fiscal instruments. Henan Province is a cradle of Chinese civilization and has a number of 
ancient heritage sites of archeological importance, many of which are either underdeveloped or 
in the state of disrepair. Development of these sites would serve to both preserve the province’s 
rich  cultural  heritage  and  enhance  its  attractiveness  as  a  destination  for  domestic  and 
international tourists. The government considers the services sector as having tremendous 
potential for generating employment and export revenues, with minimal adverse environmental 
impacts. 
 
8.  The provincial government would also like to use fiscal instruments to promote energy-
efficient  and  environmentally  sustainable  economic  growth.  It  is  critical  that  Henan  move 
towards  energy  efficiency  and  environmental  sustainability.  The  province’s  relatively  high 
dependency on energy- and raw material-intensive industries and on agriculture provides a 
significant challenge to the government in designing and implementing incentive-compatible 
policies to induce sustainable development. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The impact of the TA will be improved economic performance of Henan, relative to the 
national average, that is grounded in a better understanding of key fiscal constraints to inclusive

3
and sustainable growth. The outcome of the TA will be a superior fiscal policy regime that will 
ease binding constraints on sustainable growth in key sectors of Henan’s economy. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The TA will have two groups of outputs:   
 
(i)  A  Strategic  Report  on  Fiscal  Policy  for  Accelerating  Economic 
Development in Henan. The report will review the overall economic structure of 
Henan Province, analyze the interaction between fiscal policy and economic 
growth,  diagnose  impediments  and  key  constraints  to  growth,  and  identify 
remedial fiscal policy measures to remove impediments to sustainable growth, 
exports, and employment. It will also identify lessons for other provinces where 
possible. 
(ii)  A series of five background papers on the topics indicated below, to provide 
necessary inputs for the strategic report in (i) above. The papers will cover the 
following subjects: 
 
(a)  Overview study: improving sustainable livelihoods and promoting a 
harmonious society. The paper will analyze how fiscal policy can be used 
to enhance access to employment, education, health, and social security 
with the goal of promoting harmonious development of agriculture, industry 
and services; will make policy recommendations to remove existing fiscal 
impediments  to  sustainable  growth;  and  study  the  fiscal  management 
strengths of the Henan government.  
 
(b)  Industrial and infrastructure development and market transformation. 
The  paper  will  study  fiscal  policies  for  (1)  reforming  SOEs  in  six  key 
industrial  sectors—food  processing,  petrochemicals,  nonferrous  metals, 
automobiles  and  parts,  machine  tools,  and  textiles—with  a  view  to 
attracting private investment and modern technology into these sectors; 
(2) restructuring and modernizing basic manufacturing (industries producing 
raw materials), mining, energy (with special focus on hydropower), and 
transportation; (3) opening up Henan’s economy to external markets and 
the private sector with a view to promoting competition and investment; and 
(4) introducing fiscal instruments for promoting resource conservation and 
energy efficiency and to protect the environment and biodiversity. 
 
(c)  Modernization  of  the  services  sector.  The  paper  will  (i)  review  the 
comparative advantage of Henan Province based on its human and natural 
endowments  and  linkages  to  rest  of  the  economy,  with  a  view  to 
diversifying into a modern services sector; (ii) based on the comparative 
advantages, identify specific sectors and activities that could be promoted; 
and (iii) propose a fiscal strategy to stimulate the development of a modern 
services sector in Henan. 
 
(d)  Preservation of cultural resources. Henan has a rich cultural heritage 
and a number of ancient cultural sites and classical forms of fine arts. This 
heritage has the potential to attract both national and international visitors, 
but is currently not fully exploited due to access impediments. The paper

4   
will prepare a fiscal blueprint to preserve and develop the cultural heritage 
of Henan Province.  
 
(e)  Fiscal strategy for export promotion. Henan Province’s weak external 
trade linkages are seen as a major impediment to growth by the provincial 
government. Development policy would seek to increase the potential for 
exporting goods and services by providing fiscal incentives and investing 
public  funds  in  supporting  infrastructure.  The  paper’s  objectives  would 
include development of a fiscal blueprint for export-oriented development 
policy.  
 
11.  In addition, study tours will be organized to learn from foreign experience in the use of 
fiscal  instruments  for  regional  development,  particularly  for  (i)  promotion  of  (a)  industry, 
including  high-tech  manufacturing;  (b)  services,  including  tourism;  (c)  infrastructure;  and 
(d) renewable energy and recycling;4 and (ii) regulation of labor migration. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000 equivalent. The Government has requested ADB 
to finance $400,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding 
program. The Government will provide the remaining $150,000 of local currency costs in kind, to 
cover  office  accommodation,  counterpart  staff,  transportation,  and  other  related  services. 
Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The Ministry of Finance and ADB agreed for a partial delegation5 of TA implementation 
to the Department of Finance of Henan Province (DOF), which will be the executing agency (EA) 
for the TA. An assessment of the procurement capacity of DOF by ADB confirmed that DOF has 
the capacity to implement a delegated TA. The Institute of Fiscal Studies (IFS)6 will be the 
implementing agency. Partial delegation, in this context, would include (i) overall guidance of the 
TA; (ii) selection and engagement of the national consulting entity;7 and (iii) procurement of 
equipment, national workshops, and overseas training. ADB would assume responsibility for 
selection and engagement of the international consultant, and TA oversight.8 The provincial 
government  will  formulate  the  detailed  work plan  for  the  TA  and  implement  it  through  an 
extensive consultation process to have broad-based ownership, with wider inputs into the policy 
research studies. DOF will be assisted in the day-to-day administration of the TA by a technical 
assistance management committee.9 Overall supervision of the TA will be undertaken by DOF

of the government of Henan, the provincial academy of social sciences, and ADB.10  
 
14.  An international expert on fiscal policy with a strong background in development and 
fiscal management will be engaged by ADB for 3 person-months. DOF will recruit a single 
consulting entity to undertake the studies. DOF should apply consultant qualification selection 
(CQS)  to  recruit  the  consulting  entity.  Resource  persons  will  be  engaged  to  contribute  to 
workshops and training programs. All consultants11 for the TA will be engaged in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
Procurement under the TA will be in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
amended from time to time); the procurement method is described in the procurement plan 
(Appendix 3), which also outlines the extent of ADB oversight over various delegated activities.  
 
15.  The  TA  grant  proceeds  will  be  disbursed  in  line  with  ADB’s  Loan  Disbursement 
Handbook (2007, as amended from time to time). For withdrawal of the TA grant funds, the EA 
will submit to ADB the original withdrawal application signed by an authorized representative, a 
summary sheet, and copies of supporting documents. To facilitate implementation of the TA 
activities, following TA effectiveness DOF will establish and manage an imprest account in a 
bank acceptable to ADB. The ceiling of the imprest account will be $100,000; claims should be 
based on detailed estimated expenditure costs. The interest earned on the TA grant in the 
imprest account can be used to cover bank charges and any other remittance fees. Upon 
completion of the TA grant and before closing of the imprest account, any unutilized interest 
should be returned to ADB. If the remittance fees and other bank charges exceed the interest 
earned,  the  amount  in  excess  of  interest  earned  could  be  charged  to  the  miscellaneous 
administration expenditures of the TA. To simplify documentation, the statement of expenditure 
will be used for liquidation and replenishment of the imprest account and reimbursement of 
eligible costs for any individual payment not exceeding $10,000. Expenditures in excess of the 
statement of expenditure will be reimbursed, replenished, and liquidated based on the full 
supporting documentation. DOF is currently implementing ADB loan projects and has adequate 
financial management capabilities. DOF will maintain separate accounts for the TA grant; these 
accounts will be audited annually, with the audit report submitted to ADB within 3 months of the 
end of the fiscal year. DOF will retain the original supporting expenditure documents under the 
TA for 5 years after TA completion; during that period DOF will make these documents available 
to  ADB  for  review  upon  request.  A  diagrammatic  depiction  of  the  flow  of  funds  is  in 
Supplementary Appendix 1. 
 
16.  The international fiscal policy expert will assist the EA in TA implementation by providing 
an  international  perspective  on  development  issues,  advising  on  fiscal  policy  issues,  and 
reviewing studies to improve their quality. The international consultant will prepare output (ii)(e) 
and also assist in the preparation of outputs (i) and (ii)(a) in para. 10, with particular focus on 
strengthening  the  public  financial  management  system.  Draft  terms  of  reference  for  the 
consultants are in Appendix 4. 
 
17.  A technical support committee comprising top research institutions will be constituted to 
provide the necessary advisory, technical and peer review inputs for preparing all policy studies 
planned under the TA (the TA organization chart is in Supplementary Appendix 2). Among 
others, the technical support committee will be represented by experts drawn from (i) the

research institute of the government of Henan, (ii) the research institute of the communist party 
of Henan, (iii) provincial academy of social sciences, (iv) the University of Zhengzhou, (v) the 
University of Henan, (vi) the college of financial studies of Henan, (vii) the vocational school of 
the Henan taxation bureau, and (viii) the planning agency of the Henan provincial government. 
The national consulting entity will prepare four studies covering outputs (ii)(a)–(ii)(d) and the 
strategic study under (i) indicated in para. 10. The IFS, in addition to providing fiscal policy 
inputs  to  all  studies  as  required,  will  help  DOF  in  supervising  the  inputs  of  national  and 
international consultants. All the studies will be based on a survey of experience in other 
provinces of PRC, field work in Henan Province, international experience, and will draw on 
official and other studies and research reports. The TA will be completed in 18 months.12 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Fiscal Policy Support for Economic 
Development in Henan and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
12 The TA is expected to commence in February 2009 and end in July 2010.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be implemented by a team of experts, comprising one 
international consultant selected and engaged by the Asian Development Bank (ADB), and a 
national consulting entity selected and engaged by the executing agency (EA). The national 
consultants are responsible for all technical aspects of TA implementation and should have an 
in-depth understanding of the local fiscal environment. 
 
A.  International Fiscal Management Expert and Team Leader (3 person-months) 
 
2.  The  international  consultant  should  have  an  extensive  track  record  in  the  area  of 
development  finance,  particularly  intergovernmental  fiscal  relations  and  public  financial 
management. The consultant will assist the EA and introduce international experiences and 
best  practices  in  the  use  of  fiscal  policy  instruments,  and  assist  with  the  preparation  of 
recommendations to provincial policy makers. Prior work experience in the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC) and fluency in Mandarin are highly desirable. The international consultant is 
expected to 
(i)  assist in identifying constraints to growth in Henan, with special reference to fiscal 
policy impediments; 
(ii)  assist in the preparation of the strategic study on the use of fiscal policy for 
stimulating development in Henan, based on the findings of the sector studies;  
(iii)  review and comment on the quality of the sector-specific studies and suggest 
revisions; 
(iv)  based on international experience, and taking into account recommendations of 
the  studies  conducted  under  the  TA,  help  prepare  recommendations  for 
improving the use of fiscal instruments to accelerate economic development of 
Henan Province;  
(v)  prepare the study on a fiscal strategy for export promotion and help prepare the 
overview study on a fiscal policy for improving livelihoods; and 
(vi)  assess  the  strengths  and  weaknesses  of  provincial  fiscal  management, 
specifically  in  terms  of  comprehensiveness,  transparency,  strategic  resource 
allocation, and operational efficiency. 
 
3.  With  respect  to  development  of  a  Fiscal  Strategy  for  Export  Promotion,  the 
international consultant will  
(i)  assess and analyze the (a) state of development of the export-oriented economy, 
(b) size  and  composition  of  foreign  trade,  (c)  status  of  investment,  (d)  main 
source of exports and factors behind export growth, and (e) impediments to 
development of an export-oriented economy. 
(ii)  Review (a) fiscal policies for supporting an export-oriented economy, including 
tax incentives, subsidies, and incentives provided in industrial parks; and (b) the 
efficacy of current export promotion policies. 
(iii)  Based on the analysis of requirements for development of an export-oriented 
economy and the inputs received from the sector studies (on industry, services, 
and  cultural  resources),  set  medium-term  goals  for  export  promotion,  and 
prepare a fiscal strategy focusing on (a) appropriate reforms for needed fiscal 
investments,  (b)  establishment  of  an  investment  promotion  fund  and  rules 
governing management of such a fund, (c) policies to attract strategic investors in 
high-tech  industries,  (d)  restructuring  of  industrial  enterprises  to  establish 
transnational  enterprises,  (e)  development  of  international  markets,  and 
(f) development of agglomeration economies.

12  Appendix 4 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
3.  DOF will be responsible for planning, supervising and ensuring the quality of all studies 
planned under the TA. The department will, with inputs from the Institute for Fiscal Studies 
(IFS), identify, select, and manage national consultants and ensure the delivery of all outputs 
planned under the TA in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended  from  time  to  time).  DOF  will  work  closely  with  the  international  consultant  in 
implementing the TA. The international consultant will prepare one of the five sector papers 
required under the TA.1 The remaining studies will be outsourced to a national consulting entity. 
The IFS will add fiscal policy inputs to all studies as required.  
 
4.  The studies will (i) draw lessons from the experiences of selected provinces in the PRC 
and foreign countries; (ii) suggest forward-looking, innovative ways to use fiscal policies to 
support development; (iii) determine specific achievable outcome targets for each of the sectors 
studied; and (iv) be balanced and practical, with strong theoretical and empirical foundations, 
and of a high standard. The studies will also suggest fiscal policy measures to improve the 
quality of service delivery by government agencies. Detailed terms of reference for national 
consultants  will  be  finalized  by  DOF  when  seeking  expressions  of  interest  from  national 
consultants. The broad objectives of each of the five planned sector studies and the strategic 
study are indicated below. 
 
5.  Overview Study: Improving Sustainable Livelihoods and Promoting a Harmonious 
Society.  The objective of this paper is to design fiscal policies to promote sustainable 
employment and enhance equitable and sustainable access to basic social services (covering 
education,  health,  housing,  and  social  security).  Education  sector  policies  would  include 
supporting compulsory basic education in rural areas, providing support to poor students, and 
expanding vocational education. Health sector policies would focus on providing basic health 
care services in rural and urban areas, and developing an equitable and cost-effective health 
care  system.  This  study  will  (i)  review  the  fiscal  policies  and  impediments  to  balanced 
development of agriculture, industry and services sectors in Henan; and (ii) study the fiscal 
management strengths of the Henan government.  
6.  Industrial and Infrastructure Development and Market Transformation. In addition 
to coal mining, Henan’s industrial base is largely concentrated in six major industrial sectors—
food  processing,  petrochemicals,  textiles,  nonferrous  metals,  automobiles  and  parts,  and 
machinery—  in  which  state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs)  dominate.  These  industries  face 
challenges  due  to  a  lack  of  innovation,  weak  competitiveness,  and  low  profitability.  The 
objective of the study is to suggest fiscal policies that would help in attracting private capital to 
improve the sector’s efficiency and competitiveness. This includes the study of institutional 
reforms and policies needed to encourage SOE restructuring and privatization. To accomplish 
this the consultants will  
(i)  for each key industrial sector, conduct a diagnostic review assessing the status 
of sector development that identifies key constraints and challenges faced in 
terms of (a) institutional development, (b) the policy environment, (c) production 
efficiencies compared to the best performers in the PRC, (d) reasons for poor 
performance, and (e) internal and external threats; and 
(ii)  based  on  (i),  formulate  fiscal  policies  for  attracting  private  investment  and 
modern technology into the key industries;  
                                                 
1  The sector study on fiscal strategy for export promotion will be based on the findings of the sector studies and the 
consultant’s own study on overall fiscal policy and strengths of Henan Province’s fiscal management.

Appendix 4  13 
(iii)  include under (ii) a plan for restructuring SOEs with a view to attracting private 
investment and modern technology to enhance their competitiveness;  
(iv)  prepare policies to open up the Henan economy to external markets and the 
private sector with a view to promoting competition and attracting investment; 
(v)  take careful note of natural advantages, core competitiveness, and the future 
potential of Henan Province while formulating fiscal policies; and 
(vi)  suggest  policies  for  promoting  resource  conservation,  energy  efficiency  and 
reducing the adverse environmental impact of industry.   
 
7.  Modernization of the Services Sector. The paper will design fiscal policies to promote 
modernization of the services sector in Henan. To achieve this, the study will examine 
(i)  the current status of services in Henan and the internal structure of the sector in 
relation  to  service  sectors  in  other  provinces  in  the  PRC,  and  the  relative 
development and competitiveness of the service sector in the 18 cities in the 
province;  
(ii)  factors  that  influence  modernization  of  services,  and  how  the  sector’s 
development would influence the growth process; 
(iii)  the comparative advantage of Henan Province for developing a modern services 
sector, its competitiveness (in terms of attracting investment) compared to other 
provinces in the PRC, and impediments to service sector modernization in Henan 
Province; 
(iv)  existing fiscal (including tax and expenditure) policies to promote modernization 
of the services sector, and assess the effectiveness of existing fiscal instruments 
to stimulate modernization; and 
(v)  based  on  (iv),  assess  key  constraints  and  set  medium-term  goals  for 
modernization,  and  prepare  a  fiscal  strategy  focusing  on  (a)  needed  fiscal 
investments,  (b)  tax  incentives,  (c) the  burden  of  nontax  revenues  on  the 
services  sector,  (d)  incentive  policies  for  local  government  for  promoting 
modernization, and (e) other policies needed to create a good investment climate 
for service sector modernization. 
 
8.  Preservation of Cultural Resources. The paper will 
(i)  assess the existing state of cultural resources, the status of development of 
activities and institutions associated with cultural resources, and the problems 
that enterprises and institutions associated with cultural resources face; 
(ii)  review the existing fiscal (both tax and expenditure) policies to promote cultural 
resources and activities; examine the implementation of recent policies and their 
effectiveness;  and  compare  the  policies  pursued  by  Henan  with  successful 
policies pursued abroad, with a view to identifying weaknesses; 
(iii)  based on (ii), assess key constraints, and in collaboration with enterprises and 
institutions set medium-term goals for cultural resource development and prepare 
a  fiscal  strategy  focusing  on  (a)  needed  investments,  (b)  tax  incentives, 
(c) support  for  enterprises  and  institutions  in  the  sector,  (d)  incentives  for 
technological  innovation,  and  (e)  other  policies  needed  for  preserving  and 
developing cultural resources; and 
(iv)  assess  the  impact  of  the  development  of  cultural  resources  on  the  Henan 
economy. 
 
9.  Strategic  Report  on  Fiscal  Policy  for  Accelerating  Economic  Development  in 
Henan. Drawing on the findings of the overview report and sector reports on industry and 
infrastructure, modernization of the services sector, the development of cultural resources, and

14  Appendix 4 
 
an export promotion strategy, the strategic report will propose an overall fiscal strategy for 
accelerating economic development in Henan. The report will 
(i)  review  the  overall  economic  structure  of  Henan  Province,  its  position  in  the 
overall PRC economy, and its social development;  
(ii)  analyze the interaction between fiscal policy and economic growth and social 
development;  
(iii)  diagnose impediments and key constraints to growth and social development; 
and  
(iv)  develop a medium-term fiscal strategy to remove impediments to accelerating 
growth, employment, and exports in a sustainable manner, with a particular focus 
on  strategically important sectors.
